sub_title: Program Manager Europe & USA at Plastic Solutions Fund
summary:
I am an advocate, researcher and network coordinator who works across cultures on issues related to human rights, environmental sustainability and international development. Having worked closely with people around the globe, I’m driven to create social change through advocacy, multi-stakeholder dialogue and participatory decision-making, and the empowerment of civil society. I am skilled at crafting policy and advocacy strategies, research and documentation, mobilizing and coordinating networks and people, promoting awareness, and advocating reforms aimed at achieving systemic change. 

I have 15 years of experience working with civil society organizations on issues related to human rights, environmental justice, corporate accountability and international development. I have lived and worked at the grassroots and national levels in the Global South for 12 years, while also working with international NGOs focused on creating policy change within the international arena.

My work has appeared in Al Jazeera, BBC News, the Bangkok Post, the New York Times, the Wallstreet Journal, Reuters, the Economist, the Guardian, the Sydney Morning Herald, de Volkskrant, National Geographic, the International Bar Association, as well as in various documentaries, local newspapers and periodicals.

My areas of expertise include: policy analysis, evidence-based advocacy, strategy development and implementation, project management, strategic communications, proposal writing and fundraising strategies, capacity building trainings, community-based research, sustainable development, human rights, modern dance and choreography, geo-politics, corporate accountability, transboundary river basin management, and non-judicial grievance mechanisms.

The Plastics Solutions Fund is currently supporting projects in Asia, the United States and the European Union.

Assistance,' which was held in July 2004 at the Peace Palace in The Hague.  The 2 day conference was organized in cooperation with the emerging European network of political party foundations and looked at how Europe viewed democracy assistance abroad, particularly in response to the US government's continued justification for its involvement in the Iraq war being about building democracy. The conference brought together the Dutch Prime Minister Jan Peter Balkenende, HRH Princess Basma Bint Talal of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, Dr Madeleine Albright, former US Secretary of State, and Dr Mamphela Ramphele, Managing Director of the World Bank, among others. In conclusion, 'The Hague Statement' was produced, which called upon the European Union to
complement its two foreign policy objectives, economic cooperation and security cooperation, with
a third one: democracy assistance.
